message_1: A physics student is given a biconvex lens with a radius of curvature of 10 cm on both sides. The refractive index of the lens material is 1.5. The student needs to find the focal length of the lens when it is placed in air.

1/f = (n - 1) * (1/R1 - 1/R2)

where f is the focal length, n is the refractive index of the lens material, R1 is the radius of curvature of the first surface, and R2 is the radius of curvature of the second surface.

In this case, both surfaces have the same radius of curvature (R1 = R2 = 10 cm), and the refractive index is 1.5. Since the lens is biconvex, both surfaces are curved outward, so R1 and R2 will have the same sign. We can plug in the values into the lensmaker's formula:
